message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Using Reachable Sets for Trajectory Planning of Automated Vehicles
Paper Abstract: The computational effort of trajectory planning for automated vehicles often increases with the complexity of the traffic situation. This is particularly problematic in safety-critical situations, in which the vehicle must react in a timely manner. We present a novel motion planning approach for automated vehicles, which combines set-based reachability analysis with convex optimization to address this issue. This combination makes it possible to find driving maneuvers even in small and convoluted solution spaces. In contrast to existing work, the computation time of our approach typically decreases, the more complex situations become. We demonstrate the benefits of our motion planner in scenarios from the CommonRoad benchmark suite and validate the approach on a real test vehicle.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "convex optimization":

## Definition and Overview

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

## Key Properties

Every point that is a local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems. This is one of the most important advantages of convex optimization - it guarantees that any local optimum found is also a global optimum.

## Solution Methods

Convex optimization problems can be solved using various algorithms:

- Newton's method can be used for unconstrained or equality-constrained problems with a general convex objective that is twice-differentiable.
- Gradient descent is an efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization.
- For problems with inequality constraints, interior point methods reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function to the objective function.

## Applications

Convex optimization can be used to model problems in fields including portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, variations of statistical regression, model fitting, and electricity generation optimization.

## Software Ecosystem

There is a large software ecosystem for convex optimization, with two main categories: solvers and modeling tools.

I've completed a web search for "trajectory planning." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Trajectory optimization is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Generally speaking, trajectory optimization is a technique for computing an open-loop solution to an optimal control problem.

## Applications

There are a wide variety of applications for trajectory optimization, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. Some specific examples include:

- Robotic manipulators where redundancy can be used to optimize a trajectory to avoid obstacles inthe workspace or minimize torque in the joints
- Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters

## Related Concepts

**Kinodynamic Planning:** Kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

**Motion Planning Methods:** Real-Time Path Planning consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

**Key Algorithms:** The probabilistic roadmap planner is a motion planning algorithm in robotics, which solves the problem of determining a path between a starting configuration of the robot and a goal configuration while avoiding collisions.

I've completed the web search for "motion planning robotics." Here's a summary of the findings:

## Motion Planning in Robotics

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.

### Core Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration S and a goal configuration G, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in (possibly higher-dimensional) configuration space. A configuration describes the pose of the robot, and the configuration space C is the set of all possible configurations.

### Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video game, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

### Key Algorithms

Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.(no content)The RRT-Connect algorithm has become a key standard benchmark for sampling-based exploration of high-dimensional search spaces for robot motion planning.

### Real-Time Planning

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment, including everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously takes in information from the surroundings and creates a plan to avoid obstacles.

I've completed a web search for "autonomous vehicles." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car, driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Levels of Automation

The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies road vehicle autonomy in six levels, from Level 1 (driver assistance) where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances, to Level 5 (full autonomy), where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## Technology

Autonomous vehicle software contains several modules: the perception module that processes data from cameras, LIDAR, RADAR, and ultrasonic SONAR; the localization module that determines the vehicle's precise position using 3D point cloud data, GPS, and mapping information; and the planning module that computes actions such as velocity and steering angle outputs.

## Current Commercial Services

As of November 2025, Waymo has 2,500 robotaxis in service and is offering 450,000 paid rides per week. Additionally, Zoox officially began robotaxi service in Las Vegas in September 2025 and launched its service to the public in San Francisco in November 2025, operating through the "Zoox Explorers" program with free rides in its purpose-built autonomous vehicles.

## Regulatory Landscape

Regulation of self-driving cars, autonomous vehicles and automated driving systems is an increasingly relevant topic in the automotive industry, with multiple countries having passed local legislation and agreed on standards for the introduction of autonomous cars.

Web search results for query: "reachability analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Reachability analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis"},{"title":"Reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability"},{"title":"Reachability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_problem"},{"title":"Context-free language reachability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Context-free_language_reachability"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Petri net - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net"},{"title":"International Conference on Reachability Problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Reachability_Problems"},{"title":"Reaching definition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reaching_definition"},{"title":"Petri net unfoldings - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petri_net_unfoldings"},{"title":"Control-flow graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-flow_graph"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reachability analysis:

## Definition and Core Concept

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system consisting of local entities that communicate by message exchange.

## Results and Applications

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.(no content)The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, as well as for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

## Challenges

However, in many cases this transition graph is unbounded and can not be explored completely.(no content)A practical issue of reachability analysis is the so-called "state space explosion" — if the two entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, then the number of global states in the reachability graph can reach 100 million.

## Tools and Applications

A number of tools have been developed to automatically perform reachability analysis and model checking on the reachability graph, such as the SPIN model checker.

Reachability analysis is also used in broader contexts including reachability problems in infinite state systems, rewriting systems, dynamical and hybrid systems, Petri nets, and different computational models.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Using Reachable Sets for Trajectory Planning of Automated Vehicles". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution

**Extracted Triples (7 total):**

1. **Reachability analysis** (method, uses) - The core mathematical technique combined with optimization for the novel approach
2. **Motion planning** (method, uses) - The primary problem domain being addressed
3. **Trajectory optimization** (method, uses) - The specific trajectory planning optimization problem
4. **Convex optimization** (method, uses) - The mathematical optimization technique combined with reachability analysis
5. **Self-driving car** (task, uses) - The application domain for automated vehicles
6. **Benchmark (computing)** (data, uses) - The CommonRoad benchmark suite used for validation
7. **Motion planning** (method, proposes) - The novel combined approach the paper introduces that merges reachability analysis with convex optimization

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the JSON file meets all validation requirements, including:
- Correct paper classification as a "contribution" paper
- At least one "uses" relation (papers build on existing work)
- At least one "proposes" relation (contribution papers must create something new)
- All Wikipedia URLs are properly formatted and accessible

Sources:
- [Reachability analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis)
